 Well in practice, if you wish to deny someone their beliefs, you punish things you believe would be associated with such beliefs. For example, if you wish to prohibit the belief that "gays are evil", you punish employers who do not hire an appropriate number of gay staff, or who use certain words to describe someone. Or you prohibit them from teaching such beliefs to their children, or demand they send their children to schools where such beliefs are ridiculed.
 
 So in practice prohibiting beliefs cannot be accomplished directly, but methods can be employed to prevent the expression and transmission of such beliefs.
 
 This is of course quite different from prohibiting the implementation of certain beliefs, for example if someone believed guns were evil, they would certainly be allowed to talk about it, but the constitution would, at least in theory, prohibit them from making a law to enforce their ideals.
